docs.sourceResource.title: Le noiaphanisme, ou, système des combinaisons : nouvelle application de la vapeur pour remplacer le génie

docs.sourceResource.description: Ajeeb was presented as a chess-playing "automaton", first presented to the Royal Polytechnical Institute in 1868 by cabinet maker Charles Hooper. The mechanical technology that powered the device was fraudulent; the cabinetry housing the "machine" instead housed human players. During the time Ajeeb was active, his role was played by chess players Harry Nelson Pillsbury (1898–1904), Albert Beauregard Hodges, Constant Ferdinand Burille, Charles Moehle, and Charles Francis Barker.
docs.sourceResource.title: The Adventures of Ajeeb: The Wonderful Chess Automaton

docs.sourceResource.description: Photograph article dated November 22, 1949 partially reads, "Machines which can out-think men are being fashioned in Burbank today from cones and cylinders, networks of multi-colored wires, and systems of interlocking metal arms. The 'thinking machines' are calculating devices developed by a Burbank concern, Librascope, Inc., to perform tasks ranging from forecasting weather and matching color to relatively 'simple' problems like instantaneous multiplication. One of the machines designed at the plant at 133 E. Santa Anita Ave. is the 'automatic tristimulus integrator.' It can solve a problem in color analysis in a fraction of the time a staff of experts would require." Pictured is Lewis W. Imm, creator of 'thinking machines.'
docs.sourceResource.title: New thinking machine maze of wheels, wires

sourceResource.description: "Work ... conducted ... for the U.S. Army Electronics Command under project Michigan, contract DA-28-043-AMC-00013(E), continuation of contracts DA-36-039-SC-78801 and DA-36-039-SC-52654."
docs.sourceResource.title: A new method of simulating the central nervous system using an automatic digital computer

sourceResource.description: The Thompson Ramo Woolridge Inc. computer pictured here was part of experiment in intellectronics.
Photograph caption dated May 10, 1961 reads, "Dr. John M. Salzer Demonstrates Computer -- He is official of Thompson Ramo Wooldridge, Canoga Park."
docs.sourceResource.title: Dr. John M. Salzer demonstrates computer
